title: Best version of Garamond/Garamont
content:
Hi all,

I was looking at using Garamond for a project, but then I got so confused by the sheer amount of garamonds out there that I don't know which is the best one to use. I'm looking for a versatile version, that could also work when used in small sizes. What are the pros and cons of the different versions?

Another question related to this one is: which sans-serif font works well next to garamond? I'm doing a map related project, so possibly a font that can take a beating; by being used in small sizes and still be legible.

I hope you can help me with this one!

Thanks, Jeffrey  
 [infraordinaire](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/http/www.infraordinaire.com/wordpress)
author: Queneau

comments.content:
Jeffrey, this matter has been raised before in this forum - you can see a few links to Garamond related threads here: [http://typophile.com/node/12481](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/typophile.com/node/12481 "http://typophile.com/node/12481") (see bottom of page) - keep in mind that there have been dozens of different interpretations of Garamond typefaces.

As a personal taste, I'd go with Adobe Garamond Pro or Sabon Next, both well done and working digital typefaces.

But there can also be some interesting alternatives, like Epic [http://www.typetrust.com/font/epic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/www.typetrust.com/font/epic "http://www.typetrust.com/font/epic") or Augereau [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/abramslegacy/augereau/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/abramslegacy/augereau/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/abramslegacy/augereau/")

By the way, lists of Garamond-ish typefaces can be found here:

[http://new.myfonts.com/search/garamond/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/new.myfonts.com/search/garamond/fonts/ "http://new.myfonts.com/search/garamond/fonts/")

[http://www.identifont.com/find?font=garamond&q=Go](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/www.identifont.com/find?font=garamond&q=Go "http://www.identifont.com/find?font=garamond&q=Go")

[http://www.fontshop.com/search/?q=garamond&x=0&y=0](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=garamond&x=0&y=0 "http://www.fontshop.com/search/?q=garamond&x=0&y=0")

A sans compatible with Garamond should be a Humanist Sans, I guess. Syntax is the first that comes to mind.

Thanks for your comment.  
I thought it might have been a topic here, but I did not find it. This is very helpful!

Jeffrey  
 [infraordinaire](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/www.infraordinaire.com/wordpress)
Arno or Garamond Premier Pro would probably be my choices.

Thanks for your tip, miss tiffany.  
I think I am going for Garamond Premier Pro, as it seems to be appreciated the most around here, but I'll have a look at Arno Pro as well.

Jeffrey  
 [infraordinaire](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/www.infraordinaire.com/wordpress)
Premier Pro has the caption optical size, so I'd probably go with that if you want authentic AND small. (Arno also has this, but it's really more Jenson inspired IMO)
Dan is right. Arno is more of a Jenson. I should've mentioned that. \*slaps hands\*

I have mixed feelings about Garamond Premier Pro. Yes, it has optical sizes, and yes, it is historically more accurate than Slimbach's previous Garamond (Premier also has a wide range of glyphs and languages). But I find it too delicate, with its very detailed strokes; Garamond Pro seems more "strong" on the page, if you know what I mean (pardon my lack of technical competence). What I like in Premier, instead, is its economy - compare Premier (abobe) with Pro (below), and see how the text block looks more tight in the first paragraph.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234im_/http:/typophile.com/files/garamond_adobe_5704.jpg)

That's pretty impressive. But I guess I'm quite confused now; I like Premier being economincal, but it needs to be pretty sturdy as well. As Pro seems more strong on a page, this is a bit of a dilemma. I'll put it to the test.

Thanks!

Jeffrey  
 [infraordinaire](http://web.archive.org/web/20150306211234/http:/www.infraordinaire.com/wordpress)

Jeffrey, that was just my opinion, of course - since we are talking about typefaces of the best technical and design quality, the choice is mostly related on everyon'e eye and taste. What I find "too delicate" in Premier may be a quality for someone else. And my avatar speaks for itself.

@Queneau

Merlo works extremely well in small sizes.
